answers: Areopagus ("AIR-ee-OP-ug-giss") [or Areios Pagos or Ares Rock; accept Areopagitica]
unknown [or agnóstos; accept unknowable; accept to an unknown god; accept anything suggesting that it is not known]
Acts of the Apostles [or Práxeis tôn Apostólōn or Actus Apostolorum]
parts: Name this hill where Paul was brought to speak by the Athenians. A speech by John Milton named after this hill declares that "he who destroys a good book kills reason itself."
In his speech at the Areopagus, Paul described how he saw an altar dedicated to a god with this attribute, declaring the Christian God to be the very same god.
Paul's visit to Athens and his speech at the Areopagus are recorded in this book, placed after the gospels, describes and is named for the deeds of members of the early Christian church.
Name this phenomenon that is caused by only one member of a virtual particle-antiparticle pair escaping the event horizon.
Hawking radiation can theoretically cause these extremely massive objects to evaporate. The first "photo" of one of these objects was published in 2019.

For a black hole emitting Hawking radiation, this quantity can be written in Planck units as kappa over 2pi. This quantity is naively assigned to black holes as zero when not considering Hawking radiation.

answers: Sima Qian [or Ssu-ma Ch'ien; prompt on Tàishǐ Gōng, Lord Grand Historian, Qian, or Ch'ien]
excommunication from the Catholic Church [prompt on descriptive answers like expelling someone from the church]
parts: Identify this comet with a period of around 76 years that last appeared in 1986.
This "Grand Historian" of the Han Dynasty recorded an appearance of Halley's Comet in the Shiji, a masterwork that he completed after the death of his father.

This action was apocryphally performed on Halley's Comet in the 15th century. Years later, the Council of Trent advised great restraint in using the "sword" of this action, instead recommending censure to be used in most cases.

answers: train station [or railway station; or railroad station; or railway depot; or train depot; or railroad depot]
parts: Furness was born and worked in this city, with many Victorian-era houses now misattributed to him. Denise Scott Brown and Robert Venturi revived Furness' reputation after studying here under Louis Kahn.
This man worked for Furness's firm before moving to Chicago and, with Dankmar Adler, designing St. Louis's Wainwright Building.

Furness designed one of these buildings for the B&O Railroad. The 1963 demolition of a Beaux-Arts style building of this type in Manhattan galvanized the historic preservation movement in the United States.

answers: Catiline [or Lucius Sergius Catilina; accept Catiline conspiracy]
parts: Name this novus homo who made use of inconcinnity throughout his history of the Jugurthine War.
Another history by Sallust chronicles this man's attempt to raise an army in Etruria with the help of Gaius Manlius in 63 BC after a failed campaign for consul in his second namesake conspiracy.
Cicero, who gave the speech against Catiline, also delivered a series of Philippics against this member of the Second Triumvirate. He committed suicide after losing to Octavian at Actium.

answers: Malawi [or Republic of Malawi; accept Nyasaland]
parts: In 1974, Tanzania moved its capital from Dar es-Salaam, a city on a coast named for this language. This lingua franca of much of East Africa has many donor words from Arabic.
In 1974, this country's government announced that it would move its capital from the colonial city of Zomba, although its Parliament remained in Zomba for 20 additional years.
In January 2019, this small country on Lake Tanganyika moved its capital to the highland city of Gitega. Its former capital was Bujumbura.

answers: pi [accept pi bonds, pi orbitals, or pi electrons; prompt on delocalized; prompt on p orbitals]
parts: Give this letter which describes electrons in conjugated systems, as well as the molecular orbitals they're spread across.
When serving as ligands, anions of these elements act as pi donors due to their full octet. The weak field end of the spectrochemical series consists of ions of this group like iodide and bromide.

Conversely, pi-acceptors like carbon monoxide have antibonding pi orbitals that receive electron density from metals via this process. This process strengthens the M-L ("M L") bond at the expense of the ligand's bonds.

answers: bust of Pallas Athena [or a statue of Pallas Athena; prompt on a bust of Athena]
Helen of Troy [or Helen of Sparta; accept "To Helen"]
parts: Identify this inanimate object found "just above my chamber door" upon which the title creature is sitting in a noted poem.
The "pallid" bust of Pallas is described in this Edgar Allen Poe poem about a creature that repeatedly says, "Nevermore".

Another classical reference by Poe is his enduring couplet "the glory that was Greece, / And the grandeur that was Rome." That couplet was included in the 1845 edition of a poem titled for this figure from Greek mythology.
Name this opening aria of the 1738 opera Serse, which is sung to a plane tree by the title king. It is also known as its composer's Largo.
"Ombra mai fu" opens this composer's Serse, whose title role was premiered by the castrato Caffarelli. His other operas include Rinaldo and Giulio Cesare.
Handel's operas were performed in this language, also the original language of Christoph Gluck's Orfeo ed Euridice as well as Claudio Monteverdi's operas.

answers: Red Sorghum [or Red Sorghum Clan; or Red Sorghum Family; or Hong Gaoliang Jiazu]
wine [accept Republic of Wine; prompt on alcohol]
parts: Name this novel which tells the story of three generations of the Yu family simultaneously. While living in Shandong province, the family suffers through the Sino-Japanese War and Cultural Revolution in this novel.
Red Sorghum is a 1986 novel by this Chinese author who won the 2012 Nobel Prize. His two-syllable pen name means "Don't speak."
The Yu family use their red sorghum to make this product, a "Republic" of which titles another Mo Yan novel. The speaker drinks this alcoholic beverage "Alone by Moonlight" in a poem by Li Bai.

answers: lieutenant governor [do not accept or prompt on "governor"]
parts: Braddock was once a flourishing steel town and is home to the first of the libraries funded by and named for this man. This Scottish-American tycoon sold his company to US Steel.
Braddock's former mayor John Fetterman now serves in this position in Pennsylvania's state government. Texas unusually elects this position on its own ticket.

Fetterman gained national attention for Braddock by giving a TED Talk. A TED Talk was where Angela Duckworth popularized her ideas about this four-letter personality trait, defined as "passion and perseverance for very long-term goals."

answers: soma [or somras; or somaras; or som; accept haoma]
parts: Name this Hindi word for edible cannabis, which is sometimes drunk by Hindus mixed into a lassi or thandai (“tahn-DIE”) drink.
Bhang is traditionally consumed during this springtime Hindu "Festival of Colors." Celebrants may throw colored powder at each other during this festival.
Bhang is sometimes identified with this immortality-granting drink described in the Vedas, for which the ninth mandala of the Rig Veda is nicknamed.

answers: France [or French Republic; or République française]
African Union [or AU; or Organization for African Unity; or OAU]
parts: Identify this European country that once colonized the Ivory Coast.

This organization sanctioned Comoros after Mohamed Bacar's disputed electoral win in 2007. This 55-member organization changed its name and adopted a more economic focus in the early 2000s on the urging of Muammar al-Qaddafi.

The OAU transitioned to the AU under this world leader, who also helped secure the first World Cup held in Africa. A 2008 New York Times report linked this South African leader's AIDS denialism to over 300,000 deaths.

answers: an island [accept The Possibility of an Island] (the other novel is Lord of the Flies)
parts: Name this French author, who won the 2010 Prix Goncourt for a novel about the painter Jed Martin called The Map and the Territory.

Houellebecq defended this American politician in a 2019 essay. The protagonist's Muslim father treats this politician for a heart condition in Ayad Akhtar's Homeland Elegies and then votes for him in 2016.
The "possibility" one of these places titles a 2005 novel by Houellebecq. In a novel mostly set in one of these places, an asthmatic character's glasses are used to light a fire.
Identify this group of teenagers falsely accused of raping a jogger named Trisha Meili in 1989.

Ava DuVernay’s TV series When They See Us is about the Central Park Five. DuVernay also directed a film titled for this Alabama city, from which Martin Luther King Jr. led a voting rights march to Montgomery.

Central Park Five member Yusef Salaam went on to serve on the board of this organization, co-founded by OJ Simpson lawyers Barry Scheck and Peter Neufeld. It uses DNA testing to overturn wrongful convictions.

answers: Andrew Wiles [or Sir Andrew John Wiles]
parts: Appel ("uh-PEL") and Haken ("HAH-kun") courted controversy when they used an algorithm to complete their proof and show that 1,936 specific maps could be colored with no more than this many colors.

Gábor Fejes Tóth finished the work of his father László by declaring that Thomas Hales's proof-by-exhaustion of this conjecture was correct with "99% certainty." This conjecture states that the hexagonal and cubic close packings are the most efficient ways to pack spheres.
The formalization of how this mathematician proved Taniyama–Shimura conjecture is an eventual goal of computer verification.
Identify this town where the skeleton of Godfrey's brother Dunstan is eventually found in its Stone Pits.
Raveloe is the main setting of Silas Marner, a novella by this British author of Middlemarch.
Silas Marner was written just one year after Eliot completed The Mill on the Floss, a novel that ends with Tom and Maggie being killed in this manner after returning to St. Ogg's.

answers: United States Capitol Building [or the Capitol or Capitol Building]
parts: Name this American painter, for whom Asher Durand worked as an engraver. Durand engraved this man's portrait of Thomas Jefferson, as well as his Declaration of Independence.
Trumbull's Declaration of Independence is housed in this building's rotunda. Located in Washington, D.C., it also contains Constantino Brumidi's The Apotheosis of George Washington.
As Trumbull's mentor, this other artist encouraged him to paint Revolutionary scenes. It is not Albert Ryder, but this man painted Death on the Pale Horse.

answers: sexual reproduction [accept Origins of Sex: Three Billion Years of Genetic Recombination]
parts: Name this Lynn Margulis pioneered theory for the origin of eukaryotic cells that suggests that organelles are derived from formerly independent prokaryotes.

Margulis and James Lovelock extended endosymbiosis to the planet level with the Gaia hypothesis. Lovelock later defended the Gaia hypothesis with this simulation of a planet named for the flowers that either absorb or deflect light.
With Dorion Sagan, Margulis wrote a popular science book on the origins of this type of reproduction. Two gametes combine to produce a new organism in this type of reproduction.
Name this 19th-century philosopher, who created his Naturphilosophie in opposition to the thought of his mentor Fichte.
Schelling's philosophy of nature is often interpreted as a version of this position. In general, this position equates God with nature or the universe.
Schelling’s System of Transcendental Idealism further develops the ideas of this predecessor of his,who expounded the philosophy of “transcendental idealism” in his Critique of Pure Reason.
Name this city, whose archives were stolen by Thomas Smith and Eli Chandler during an 1842 war. Mirabeau Lamar chose this city as the final capital for a Republic.

This first President of Texas ordered Thomas Smith and Eli Chandler to move the archives from Austin to Washington-on-the-Brazos. This man, who names Texas' most populous city, defeated Santa Anna at the Battle of San Jacinto.

Stephen F. Austin, Austin's namesake, was one of these entrepreneurs who were granted the right to settle Texas by the Mexican government. The Old Three Hundred settled in land granted to these people.
